title: 110_s1086
content:
The "Cyber Safety for Kids Act of 2007" prohibits commercial websites from containing harmful material for minors. The "Cyber Safety for Kids Act of 2007" prohibits commercial websites from knowingly placing harmful material for minors unless specific restrictions are in place, including age verification requirements and content description tags assigned by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration will develop a content description tag for websites containing harmful material for minors, allowing consumers to block access. SEC. 3. REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS. Any website operator registering or re-registering with ICANN must provide operator name, website URL, IP address, and content description tag. The Secretary of Commerce must work with ICANN within 30 days to fulfill this requirement. The Secretary of Commerce must make amendments to existing agreements with ICANN to fulfill registration requirements. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT.

Any person who violates this Act shall be subject to civil penalties as prescribed by the Secretary of Commerce. The Secretary of Commerce has the power to enforce the Act, including requirements for registrants under section 3 and the collection of civil penalties.

SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions for ICANN, Internet, and material harmful to minors are provided. ICANN refers to the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. The Internet is a global network of computer networks using TCP/IP to transmit information. Material harmful to minors includes obscene content or material that a reasonable person would find inappropriate. The text defines what is considered harmful material to minors, stating that it must appeal to prurient interest, be patently offensive, and lack serious value for minors. A minor is defined as a person under 18 years of age. The term "minor" refers to a person under 18 years of age. The term "source code" includes text and characters on a webpage. A "tag" is a keyword describing information for classification and filtering. The term "website" refers to material accessible on the Internet via a computer server-based file archive using hypertext transfer protocol.
